title: Zarqawi group added to U.S. terrorism list
full text:
The group headed by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, which has claimed responsibility for dozens of deadly attacks in Iraq and the beheading of hostages, was designated by the U.S. government yesterday as a terrorist organization.
The State Department has considered Zarqawi a threat for some time.
Spokesman Richard Boucher called the Jordanian a horrible criminal responsible for the murders of many Iraqis, Americans and others.
The United States is trying to hunt down terrorists around the world, he said, and "this is one of them we intend to catch."
With terrorism a major campaign issue, Rand Beers, Democratic candidate John Kerry's national security adviser, said: "It is inexplicable that President Bush waited until today to shut down" Zarqawi's finances.
Beers said in a statement that "this is yet another example of President Bush's failure to effectively prosecute the war in Iraq or the war on terror."
Before Beers issued his statement, Boucher told reporters that placing the group on the terror list required going through a drawn-out legal process to be effective.
The reward for information leading to Zarqawi's killing or capture was raised to $25 million this summer, putting him on a par with al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden and bin Laden's top deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri.
The listing imposes several restrictions on Zarqawi's group, Tawhid and Jihad, including a ban on travel to the United States and a freeze on the group's assets in U.S. banks. In practice, however, the listing has limited implications.
On a parallel track, the United States, Britain and Iraq are asking the U.N. Sanctions Committee to list the Zarqawi group as well, which would impose identical sanctions worldwide.
